poem:
**Harold in Shade**

In the museum of forgotten minds,
where legacy turns paper thin,
Wilson wanders past
bright halls of rhetoric,
fingers trembling, tracing
lost elections and half-remembered
policies. Promises fade
like old photographs,
but in the corners,
whispers of tenacity persist,
where even memory's thief
cannot steal the parchment
of the heart.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sad last days of Harold Wilson revealed by Cabinet Office archives Margaret Thatcher described him as “the most skilful of politicians” and Tony Blair thought him “Labour’s most successful leader ever”. Such elegies on the death in 1995 of Harold Wilson, 79, the twice Labour prime minister who had Alzheimer’s and colon cancer, betray nothing of the reality of his later years – spent in the unforgiving grip of dementia and, it has emerged, forced". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
